title: Citi analyst sees JPMorgan beating earnings target as a 'stronger conviction' buy; Citi includes JPMorgan in its short list of stronger conviction buys along with Goldman Sachs, Comerica and Bank of New York Mellon
text:
Horowitz said bank stocks remain "oversold due to credit concerns."

Also Read: Jamie Dimon says stopping oil and gas funding would be 'road to hell for America'

Citi expects JPMorgan to set a strong tone at the start of earnings season when it provides its third-quarter update on Oct. 14. Analysts are currently forecasting third-quarter earnings of $2.93 a share for JPMorgan, according to FactSet data.

"We believe a 3Q earnings beat on the top line will lead to upward revisions on full-year guidance and imply a better run-rate into 2023," Horowitz said.

Also Read: Credit Suisse woes prompt calls to analysts asking if U.S. banks risk a 'contagion impact'

Citi expects JPMorgan to revise upward its outlook for net interest income, which is the profit generated from issuing loans at a higher interest rate than it pays customers for their deposits.

"They have been more disciplined than others on being patient to deploy cash, and now have the opportunity to extend duration at higher rates," Horowitz said of JPMorgan.

Citi also upgraded Bank of New York Mellon Corp. to buy from neutral on expectations for strong net interest income as well as high return of capital, with expense control by its new management team.

"BK remains in a very strong position from a capital perspective and net interest income outlook, partly offset by headwinds on fees," Horowitz said.

Citi also cut its rating on M&T Bank Corp. MTB to neutral from buy because of a lack of relative upside in the stock.

Horowitz initiated a pair trade of overweight Wells Fargo & Co. WFC and underweight Truist Financial TFC.

"Both stocks have had similar performance since February, but we see high risk for negative earnings per share revisions for TFC largely on net interest income and expenses, while we believe WFC is well positioned," Horowitz said. "While credit risk profile is good for both banks, TFC does have some higher risk portfolios (which have very strong risk adjusted returns), which could put more pressure on credit losses. "

Shares of JPMorgan Chase are down 29.6% in 2023, compared to an 17.1% loss by the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Goldman Sachs shares are down 18.9% and Comerica stock is down 13.2% in 2022, while Bank of New York Mellon shares are down 29.2%. Wells Fargo stock is down 10.5% in 2022 and Truist Financial is off by 21.7%.
